reviewText: Drawing on his brother Ken Burns' successful formula, Ric Burns' 2-hour documentary is a pioneering work of history that will shock and grieve viewers of this lesser studied aspect of the Civil War. It is as good as a documentary of this type can get. Screened on PBS in 2012, D&tCW; is a classic.The film is structured around the careful use of period photographs, a la Ken Burns Civil War series. But Ric Burns also uses tinted photographs - a style in favor during the 1860s - infusing the morbid subject with a subtle and haunting sense of life. Additionally, he stages these photographs in their Victorian period frames, placing them on table tops with oil lamps and family Bibles -- in darkened domestic interiors, shot with color film. This dramatic device serves to remind viewers that these deaths "came home" -- even if the bodies often did not. The parlor table became the memorial for the fallen and vanished soldier.Appropriately, most of the interviewees speak in soft, almost hushed, voices, including the Harvard Historian, Drew Gilpin Faust, whose book, The Republic of Suffering, was the basis for the film. The voices of wives and mothers -- North and South -- are heard throughout and are tinged with anguish and mourning. The actors are reading from memoirs and letters from the era. The somber and gripping opening of D&tCW; has a dying Confederate soldier's letter quaveringly voiced as he bids farewell to his Mississippi family. The camera scans down the actual (candlelit) letter and we see the faltering penmanship as the soldier must have struggled to complete his letter before his life slipped away.Viewers will be stunned to learn the amount of bodies left on battlefields, whether hastily buried or abandoned to rot. The federal program to reclaim these bodies for an honorable and dignified burial lasted some 2 years after the war. This had to be done quickly as bitter Southerners whose lands and cities were laid waste often desecrated the bodies of the Union dead. And since the federal recovery/burial program ignored the interment of the Confederate fallen, private societies of Southern ladies were formed and they ventured to battlefields like Gettysburg to reclaim and bury their dead, rescuing the remains from Northern antipathy. As a result Union and Confederate were buried in separate cemeteries, reinforcing the national division. These efforts lasted into the 1870s.For additional information on Americans and their responses to the deaths of loved ones in the Civil War, as well as the culture the war produced, see also:This Republic of Suffering: Death and the American Civil War (Vintage Civil War Library)Upon the Altar of the Nation: A Moral History of the Civil WarAnd the Civil War in our time as it is "used" in contemporary society, especially the South, see Tony Horwitz's moving and humorous account:Confederates in the Attic: Dispatches from the Unfinished Civil War
summary: a heart-rending revelation of the war's unprecedented casualties

reviewText: Having read quite a bit about the Civil War I was aware of a lot of the problems not usually discussed when the topic comes up.  It's unfathomable to think of one of our soldiers now going into battle now days without ID.  There are thousands of soldiers who were lost during the Civil War who will never come home due to a oversight by both sides and the mistaken belief that the war would be short.  The recovery of the bodies after the war was over was a monumental task and the remains of those identified and recovered was extensive but they couldn't find or identify them all.  After many of the battles the victors were left with the daunting task of burying the dead from both  sides.  It wasn't always done with care and many ended up in mass or unmarked graves.  This DVD, American Experience: Death & The Civil War is an attempt to document the task of bringing the dead home

reviewText: The American Civil War, fought from 1861 to 1865, would have a profound effect on the country both during and after the war. One of probably the biggest effects the war would create on the people both in the north and south was dealing with death. For the first time Americans had to suddenly deal with death on a large scale. As the war dragged on and battle after battle producing thousands of dead soldiers that had to be dealt with Americans came to see and deal with death in a whole new way. Neither side at the beginning of the war had any kind of system to clear the dead from the battlefield or dispose of the bodies. But it soon became clear something had to be done to help relieve the problems that the military and its citizens came face to face with with the end of every battle."American Experience: Death and The Civil War" looks at the situations that would arise from the war and how it would come to effect everyone and how it would change their views on death and dying. This is a grim subject matter to be sure. However it is an interesting look at how American society would come to change how it looked at death and prepared for it. I am a history nerd and a Civil War buff so I am sure this is something only historians would only find interesting to watch. It is I will admit a bit slow and dull at places but I would still recommend this to anyone to watch whether you are into history or not. Though a grim subject this documentary is still an interesting and important look at how an event like the Civil War would effect the country then and still effects the country today 150 years after the end of the war.

reviewText: This documentary is the usual excellent Public Television work and deals in an interesting way with a little-known issue arising from the Civil War ... how we deal with our war dead. People who enjoy American Experience docs will almost certainly enjoy this one, despite how grim the subject is. The up side is the improvements made by the U.S. to how we identify, transport and render our final respects to our war dead. This doc shows how our country responded intelligently, compassionately and effectively to the horrendous loss of life caused by the Civil War.

reviewText: This film has a great many very deeply distressing and graphic pictures of battlefield dead and bloody letters home. Its' main point however seemed to me to be the role of the Civil War as the catalyst for national military cemeteries, casualty identification and recovery of remains, and the notification of next of kin---none of which was existent before the war. It speaks of the traditional role of the family in caring for the remains of their dead (including battlefield recovery of remains) and the change from that model of death as a private family matter to the current systems in place for the care and honor of the dead and their families. This is especially relevant to the first-settled areas of the nation, north and south, with the small family burying grounds, and even the construction of houses with "coffin doors" (narrow but double front doors swinging outward which were so built in order to permit removal of the casket from the house to the burying ground).
